Text:
Is the Silverlight hosted on the same domain as the webservice? If that isn't the case you need to create a clientaccesspolicy.xml file.

[See here][1]


  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc197955(VS.95).aspx

Example:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
    <access-policy>
      <cross-domain-access>
        <policy>
          <allow-from http-request-headers="SOAPAction">
            <domain uri="*"/>
          </allow-from>
          <grant-to>
            <resource path="/" include-subpaths="true"/>
          </grant-to>
        </policy>
      </cross-domain-access>
    </access-policy>

Is the Silverlight hosted on the same domain as the webservice? If that isn't the case you need to create a clientaccesspolicy.xml file.

[See here][1]


Example:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
    <access-policy>
      <cross-domain-access>
        <policy>
          <allow-from http-request-headers="SOAPAction">
            <domain uri="*"/>
          </allow-from>
          <grant-to>
            <resource path="/" include-subpaths="true"/>
          </grant-to>
        </policy>
      </cross-domain-access>
    </access-policy>

**Update**:
If you install [Fiddler][2], you will be able to quickly confirm if it's indeed a crossdomain issue.


  [1]: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc197955(VS.95).aspx
  [2]: http://www.fiddler2.com/fiddler2/
